 We've always had a standard in one form or another, be it beads, gold, the USD for a period, Swiss Franc, trade guarantees, etc., all dictated by economic strength of the issue. I can't recall past ratios when gold was a world standard (not primary exchange), but 5% of outstanding national currency issues as a reserve seems familiar. The current trend seems to be leaning more towards stability of grouped individual currencies, shedding or adding on economic fluctuations, with most nations not politically tied to any one currency holding the most stable as reserves. 
 
 The USD/Euro is, IMO, an excellent example of the trend to mixed basket reserves. While a good part of the swing to Euros is due to US fiscal irresponsibility and deceptive financial reporting (no secret to anyone other than general populations), the fact that EU countries are demanding and receiving 'honest' financial reporting from those members participating in the Euro (Greece as an example) says much about trade balance still being the world standard regardless of what's used as an exchange. Technology has eliminated currency and trade float and we're seemingly headed back in a direction of a world currency or three dictated by current financial reporting based on commodity exchange rather than political influence.
